verses.text: The book of the genealogy of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham:
verses.comment: Matthew's opening connects Jesus directly to the promises made to Abraham and David, showing that Jesus is the long-promised Messiah. This highlights the importance of lineage in fulfilling prophecy.

verses.text: Abraham fathered Isaac, and Isaac fathered Jacob, and Jacob fathered Judah and his brothers.
verses.comment: This verse traces the Messianic line through the patriarchs, affirming God's faithfulness to His covenant people.

verses.text: Judah fathered Perez and Zerah by Tamar, and Perez fathered Hezron, and Hezron fathered Ram.
verses.comment: The mention of Tamar highlights how God works through unexpected people and circumstances for His purposes. The genealogy includes men and women with complex histories.

verses.text: Ram fathered Amminadab, and Amminadab fathered Nahshon, and Nahshon fathered Salmon.
verses.comment: The genealogy continues showing Jesus' royal and priestly heritage.

verses.text: Salmon fathered Boaz by Rahab, and Boaz fathered Obed by Ruth, and Obed fathered Jesse.
verses.comment: Rahab and Ruth, both Gentiles, are featured in Christ's genealogy, foreshadowing God’s inclusion of all nations. This underlines the importance of grace and spiritual adoption.

verses.text: Jesse fathered David the king. David fathered Solomon by the wife of Uriah.
verses.comment: Matthew highlights David as king and Solomon as a result of forgiveness and grace, revealing God’s power to redeem even human failure. This stresses the legitimacy of Christ’s royal lineage.

verses.text: Solomon fathered Rehoboam, and Rehoboam fathered Abijah, and Abijah fathered Asa.
verses.comment: Each generation matters in the unfolding of God's salvation plan through the house of David.

verses.text: Asa fathered Jehoshaphat, and Jehoshaphat fathered Joram, and Joram fathered Uzziah.
verses.comment: Matthew selects key names from the Davidic line, simplifying the genealogy for theological emphasis (see also Matt 1:17).

verses.text: Uzziah fathered Jotham, and Jotham fathered Ahaz, and Ahaz fathered Hezekiah.
verses.comment: Despite some kings' failings, the Messianic line continued. God’s promises override human shortcomings.

verses.text: Hezekiah fathered Manasseh, and Manasseh fathered Amos, and Amos fathered Josiah.
verses.comment: Even through sinful or lesser-known rulers, the genealogy presses on, revealing that God's plan is not thwarted by man’s failures.

verses.text: Josiah fathered Jeconiah and his brothers, at the time of the deportation to Babylon.
verses.comment: The exile is a key moment. Despite judgment, the promise of a coming Messiah remains, pointing to hope and restoration.

verses.text: After the deportation to Babylon, Jeconiah fathered Shealtiel, and Shealtiel fathered Zerubbabel.
verses.comment: Zerubbabel is a leader in the restoration after the exile—a sign of new beginnings and God’s renewed faithfulness.

verses.text: Zerubbabel fathered Abiud, and Abiud fathered Eliakim, and Eliakim fathered Azor.
verses.comment: These names, not found directly in the Old Testament, show how tradition preserved certain key links to Christ. The precision of the genealogy upholds continuity and authority.

verses.text: Azor fathered Zadok, and Zadok fathered Achim, and Achim fathered Eliud.
verses.comment: The genealogy moves quietly through the centuries, demonstrating God’s silent, providential guidance of history.

verses.text: Eliud fathered Eleazar, and Eleazar fathered Matthan, and Matthan fathered Jacob.
verses.comment: Each generation paves the way for Christ. This unseen succession hints at how the Lord prepares His people in silence as well as in action.

verses.text: Jacob fathered Joseph the husband of Mary, of whom Jesus was born, who is called Christ.
verses.comment: Matthew is precise: Jesus is born of Mary, not of Joseph, emphasizing Christ’s virginal conception. This confirms His divine origin and fulfillment of prophecy.

verses.text: So all the generations from Abraham to David are fourteen generations, and from David to the deportation to Babylon fourteen generations, and from the deportation to Babylon to the Christ fourteen generations.
verses.comment: Matthew’s structure shows God’s hand working in history and points to Jesus as the climax of salvation history.

verses.text: Now the birth of Jesus Christ happened in this way: When his mother Mary was betrothed to Joseph, before they came together, she was found to be with child by the Holy Spirit.
verses.comment: Matthew stresses Mary’s virginity and the supernatural work of the Spirit, affirming the miraculous and unique nature of Christ’s birth. The phrase 'before they came together' underlines her purity.

verses.text: Joseph, her husband, being a righteous man and unwilling to put her to shame, resolved to divorce her quietly.
verses.comment: Joseph's mercy toward Mary goes beyond the letter of the law. This introduces his obedience and humility, qualities necessary for his unique vocation.

verses.text: But as he considered these things, behold, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream, saying, 'Joseph, son of David, do not fear to take Mary as your wife, for that which is conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit.'
verses.comment: God communicates through an angel, affirming the heavenly origin of Jesus. The greeting 'son of David' reminds us of Joseph's place in the royal lineage, essential for Jesus' fulfillment of Messianic prophecy.

verses.text: 'She will bear a son, and you shall call his name Jesus, for he will save his people from their sins.'
verses.comment: 'Jesus' means 'Yahweh is salvation.' The Christ-child is not only a savior from political oppression, but the One who saves from sin, underlying his divine mission.

verses.text: All this took place to fulfill what the Lord had spoken by the prophet:
verses.comment: Matthew emphasizes fulfilled prophecy, showing the continuity and unity between God’s work in the Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: "Behold, the virgin shall conceive and bear a son, and they shall call his name Immanuel" (which means, God with us).
verses.comment: Immanuel means 'God with us,' testifying to the reality of God becoming man. This is a clear statement of Christ’s divine nature and presence among His people.

verses.text: When Joseph woke from sleep, he did as the angel of the Lord commanded him. He took his wife,
verses.comment: Joseph's obedience here is instantaneous and complete, providing a model of faithfulness to divine instruction.

verses.text: but did not know her until she had given birth to a son. And he called his name Jesus.
verses.comment: The phrase 'did not know her until' emphasizes Mary's virginity before Jesus’ birth, in fulfillment of prophecy. The early Church unanimously affirmed this perpetual purity, showing deep reverence for the mystery of Christ’s incarnation.
